In November of 2011, Polish Airlines Captain

392.26.text:

Airport, after a long flight from New Jersey.

397.60.text:
“I have flown this plane 500 times,” he
would later tell the astonished press, “and

402.38.text:
this is the first time the undercarriage did
not open.”

405.24.text:
The plane had suffered a massive failure of

408.80.text: gear would not be making an appearance.

411.07.text:
After relaying the situation to his 231 passengers

416.87.text:

421.02.text:

But the hour of circling had depleted most

452.26.text:
We’re not sure Batman could have done any

That would have been scary enough on its own,

in fact, it was speeding up, approaching 70

The driver was experiencing a medical emergency,

524.07.text: Cruise Ship Almost Crashes Into Bridge

526.58.text:
Captain Peter Liley was operating the Carnival
cruise ship Pacific Dawn on Australia’s

531.37.text:
Brisbane River in April 2010, when the ship
suddenly lost power.

536.62.text:
It had suddenly become an enormous, drifting
hulk, 700 yards up river from the crowded

543.14.text:
Captain and crew remained calm, even briefing
passengers on what was happening, as the ship

547.33.text: bore down on the six-lane bridge.

549.67.text:
The captain was quite concerned about the
possibility of the ship ramming the bridge’s

553.57.text:
pylons – a concern he did not share with
the passengers.

556.64.text:
As he steered the powerless ship, two tugboats
attached themselves, and began pulling mightily

560.96.text: in the opposite direction of the bridge.

563.03.text:
Incredibly, they were able to bring the disabled
liner to a full stop, less than 100 yards

568.99.text:
The ship was towed back to port, where it
was determined that a faulty fuse, due to

572.74.text: a saltwater leak, was to blame.

574.74.text:
Amazingly, a Carnival Australia spokesman
asserted that it had been a “controlled

579.14.text:
situation,” the result of a “temporary
loss of power,” and the ship headed on out

582.48.text:

588.30.text:
In August 1963, 27-year old Captain Victor
Mostovoy was at the controls of an Aeroflot

593.84.text: Tupolev Tu-124 passenger jet bound for Moscow.

597.47.text:
It became apparent that something was amiss
shortly after takeoff; the landing gear failed

602.03.text:
to retract properly, and were stuck in an
awkward position.

605.46.text:
The decision was made by ground control to
divert the flight to Leningrad, and the plane

609.71.text:
made several loops over that city’s airport
to burn off fuel.

612.96.text:
One out of fuel, one engine quit, and then
the other.

615.98.text:
The airliner was now a very large, not-too-maneuverable
glider, with 52 terrified people aboard.

622.28.text:
The plane was over the center of the city
by this point, too far from the airport to

625.71.text:
even attempt a runway landing, and the crew
determined that their only choice of runway

629.72.text: was now the 980-foot wide Neva River.

633.36.text:
Water landings were known to not go terribly
well as a general rule, and this particular

637.21.text:
river had three bridges along its length that
Mostvoy would have to contend with; but the

641.30.text:
Neva being their only option, he took the
plane down.

644.41.text:
The first bridge, the Liteyny, they cleared
by a good 300 feet.

646.35.text:
The second, the Bolsheokhtinsky, was passed
with less than a hundred feet of clearance.

648.83.text:
The last, the Alexander Nevsky Bridge, damn
near got a face full of plane, with screaming

652.86.text:
construction workers leaping into the river
when they saw the plane approach.

656.82.text:
The plane splashed down on the river’s surface,
right next to a trusty late-1800’s tugboat.

662.02.text:
The tugboat captain broke the plane’s windshield,
secured a cable to the cockpit control wheel,

666.52.text:
and proceeded to tow the flooding plane – with
all the passengers and crew still aboard – to

670.44.text:
the river bank, where they were evacuated,
luggage and all.

673.57.text:
Shortly, a bus came along to take everyone
to the airport.

676.22.text: Ho hum, just another flight to Moscow.
